Reclaiming-Nostalgia-to-Resist-the-Prese.content:
Grafton Tanner reclaims our right to nostalgia, too often snatched away by â€˜foreverismâ€™â€”the drive to make the past perpetually present at any cost. Nostalgia, in contrast, allows us to critically distance ourselves from the promises of a system that wants no future for us.

{There might be translation errors due to the model used. Written originally in Catalan}
Itâ€™s Friday night after dinner. You sit on the couch, turn on the TV, and there they areâ€”Jordi SÃ¡nchez and Joel Joan in a bar. You, a lifelong fan ofÂ Plats BrutsÂ since early childhood, widen your eyes like saucers: finally, the spin-off weâ€™ve been waiting for! But the joy lasts only minutes. You notice the forced dialogue, the stiff expressions, the artificial set. Of courseâ€”itâ€™s TV3â€™s 40th-anniversary gala! For some reason, a bittersweet unease washes over you, a strange discomfort. Is this nostalgia? If Grafton Tanner is right, this feeling has less to do with clamoring forÂ Plats Brutsâ€™ return (as youâ€™ve tweeted so often) and more to do with the ghostly spectacle youâ€™ve just witnessed.
The Order of Nostalgic Discourse
Grafton Tanner, an American writer and academic, has gained recent prominence in cultural studies. He published his first essay on vaporwave in 2016, but his focus on nostalgia began in 2020 withÂ The Circle of the SnakeÂ and solidified in his most ambitious work to date,Â The Hours Have Lost Their ClockÂ (2021), translated last year by Tigre de Paper. A few months ago, the third installment of this trilogy appeared:Â Foreverism, where Tanner resolves many lingering questions and redefines concepts that will deeply influence current debates. Introducing new philosophical terms is never easy, and in this country, weâ€™re often late to the game. Thatâ€™s why I appreciate Oriol Rossellâ€™s swift adoption of â€œforeverismâ€ in Catalan barely two weeks after the bookâ€™s UK release. Kudos, too, to Tigre de Paper for translating such a workâ€”rarely do we get Catalan editions before Spanish or French ones.
InÂ Foreverism, Tanner defines nostalgia as an emotion â€œcapable of generating and reinterpreting memory,â€ contrasting it with modern ideologies of moral progress. This description carries political implications far removed from its original meaning. The term â€œnostalgiaâ€ was coined in 1688 when Swiss student Johannes Hofer, in his doctoral thesis, diagnosed it as an illnessâ€”a melancholic longing for homeland that plagued Swiss mercenaries abroad, clouding their minds and even endangering their lives.
Tanner revives this â€œmedicalization of nostalgiaâ€â€”a discourse later blended with atavism and social Darwinism, morphing into a political weapon against cultural minorities and non-hegemonic identities, framing nostalgia as a primitive trait to overcome. He calls â€œpositivist discourses on nostalgiaâ€ those medico-legal arguments that opposed it to civilizational progress, condemning its unsettling ability to detach people from the presentâ€”the time of labor, production, and capital. After the World Wars, medical discourse on nostalgia faded, and positivist rhetoric became an awkward relic, reducing nostalgia to mere consumer goods.
Yet Tanner rejects any narrative implying nostalgia has â€œprogressedâ€â€”from disease to disorder to commodity. He detects in this trajectory the same goal as the old â€œpositivist discourseâ€: making us believe nostalgia is no longer what it once was. Nostalgia hasnâ€™t vanished; itâ€™s locked in a battle with a new discourse seeking to erase it:Â foreverism.
Foreverism: When Nothing Is Missing, We Miss Nothing
Tanner definesÂ foreverismÂ as a dominant contemporary cultural and political discourse that keeps the past perpetually present, creating the illusion that society is endlessly looking backward. He reclaims the term from digital marketing blogs that, a decade ago, pushed a â€œpermanent beta modeâ€ for all products: constant updates, never-ending conversations, unfinished goods. Foreverism offers a past disguised as the present; like positivism, it aims to eliminate nostalgiaâ€”not through discipline, but through the illusion of free consumption. It forces us to mistake the flood of â€œpastâ€ content on our screens for nostalgic desire when, Tanner suspects, the truth is simpler: the West has never coexisted peacefully with nostalgia and remains haunted by it as in centuries past.
The goal is no longer preservation (only the dead can be preserved) or restoration (an endless process)â€”itâ€™s toÂ foreverizeÂ the world. Strategies include:


Perpetual accessibilityÂ (cloud-stored photos, entire streaming catalogs).


AI-remastered media, scrubbing away â€œthe aesthetic of decay,â€ the Benjaminian patinaâ€”colorizing images, removing audio crackle, sanitizing results as if recorded with todayâ€™s technology. But some truths, Tanner writes, â€œcan only be uncovered by engaging with an objectâ€™s idiosyncrasies.â€ Remasters simulate an â€œauthenticâ€ past while pushing the real past further away.


Political Exceptionalism and Narrative Persistence
Foreverismâ€™s hallmark isÂ endless storytelling: every movie a franchise, every series indefinitely extended, every audiovisual product reduced to â€œcontentâ€â€”â€œeasily consumed, just as easily forgotten,â€ making way for the next sequel. Tanner argues this mimics a childâ€™s sense of infinity, replicating in fiction the illusion of progress the system can no longer deliver. For the culture industry, itâ€™s a safe bet: audience flops are avoided, and franchises lingering in stores and theaters trick the public into believing they need never end, since nothing better will come. Critics say weâ€™ve grown nostalgicâ€”but how can we miss whatâ€™s never truly finished?
This persistence reshapes contemporary subjectivity. Amid the biopolitics of permanent exception (summed up in Tannerâ€™s phrase, â€œItâ€™s not a matter ofÂ if, butÂ whenâ€), foreverist subjectivity demands constant vigilanceâ€”never miss out, always improve, adapt endlessly. Though increasingly aware of material limits, the foreverized world seems to expand infinitely, exhausting its inhabitants. The nostalgic individual, once medically and politically â€œcorrectedâ€ for failing to embrace Enlightenment progress, now endures market-based therapy: consuming foreverized pasts, trapped in patterns of longing for what feels ever more unattainable. Like Deleuzeâ€™s shift from disciplinary societies to control societies, nostalgia, too, has moved from discipline to control. If nostalgic restoration fuels capitalist labor, itâ€™s permittedâ€”even encouraged. Otherwise, the system prefers amnesiac subjects, too immersed in the present to remember.
Nostalgic Energy and Political Restoration
Tannerâ€™s work might seem like another cultural critique of late capitalismâ€”but its aim is sharper: to expose how foreverist cultural discourse fuels so-called â€œnostalgic politics.â€ The resurgence of reactionary politics this past decade is no accident; its catalyst was power structures selling the myth of an irrecoverable past, scapegoating queer theory, Global South migrants, woke movements, etc. Here lies Tannerâ€™s importance: he gives us tools to doubt the â€œnostalgicâ€ core of such politics. These movements exploit nostalgic energy, but their strategy suspiciously resembles foreverismâ€”declaring the past lost, promising its eternal restoration, then mobilizing followers to labor emotionally for it. Trump doesnâ€™t want voters toÂ missÂ Americaâ€™s past; he foreverizes it, stifling nostalgia altogether.
NostalgiaÂ itselfÂ isnâ€™t productive: it isolates, paralyzes. Capitalism needs workers who produce and consume. Reactionary politics mobilizes people to restore the pastâ€”to work, not rest. But the past is impossible to restore, let alone foreverize! Wasted effort breeds rage and despair as the present grows unlivable, the past recedes, and the promised future-past never arrives.
Tanner argues that foreverist discourses, like Trumpâ€™s, aim to suppress nostalgia and other emotions threatening capitalist oppressionâ€”just as doctors, psychiatrists, and judges once did. Nostalgia challenges moral progress narratives, the myth that we live in the best possible world. It distances us from immediacy, lets us compare expectations, recall broken promises. And it wonâ€™t be easily eradicated: no matter how much access or artificial revival we have, weâ€™ll never truly â€œreliveâ€ the pastâ€”and the possibility of missing it will always remain.
Reclaiming Nostalgia, Resisting the Present
Foreverism has replaced old positivist anti-nostalgia discourses because it better solves capitalismâ€™s eternal problem: how to profit from the past while stamping out longing for it. As Tanner shows, foreverism still seeks to suppress emotions that threaten the work-and-produce orderâ€”even the labor of keeping the past alive. When nothing ends, when everything stays present, feelings tied to finalityâ€”satisfaction, relief, but also grief and nostalgiaâ€”mutate into anger and hopelessness. Foreverismâ€™s trap is promising to soothe these feelings while breeding fiercer ones.
Tannerâ€™sÂ The Hours Have Lost Their ClockÂ tentatively proposed reclaiming our right to nostalgia. Now, he goes further: perhaps too much is blamed on â€œnostalgia,â€ while the real thingâ€”ourÂ nostalgiaâ€”is far rarer. His solution: let it exist as just another emotion, neither politicized nor commodified. Feeling nostalgic might, at times, be goodâ€”even necessaryâ€”to make sense of past and future.
But reclaiming nostalgia demands surgical precision with language and critique, separating the wheat of nostalgia from the chaff of foreverism. It means watching thatÂ Plats BrutsÂ reunion and asking: Will a spin-off, or rewatching it on 3Catâ€™s foreverist platform, ever replace the ache of first seeing it? We must ask: Is our nostalgia a desire for endless franchise content, a wish to restore society as it was, or grief for what that past failed to deliver?
With Tannerâ€™s latest work, drawing the line is easier:Â â€œnostalgiaâ€Â is the deep longing for the past;Â â€œforeverismâ€Â is the discourse begging us to relive itâ€”only to perpetuate capitalismâ€™s promise thatÂ nowÂ is forever, and forever isÂ now. If nothing is allowed to change, the enemy, as Walter Benjamin wrote, will never stop winning.â€

The-golden-age-and-the-lost-home.title: The golden age and the lost home
The-golden-age-and-the-lost-home.content:
Now that our homes are at risk in the hands of vulture funds, now that our homelands burn, we need to make our nostalgias dialogue without reducing them to Donald Trumpâ€™s agenda or Bad Bunnyâ€™s music.

In mid-January, a new trend spread across social networks, under the guise of a song from Bad Bunnyâ€™s new album:Â DebÃ­ tirar mÃ¡s fotosÂ invited us to remember everything weâ€™ve lost, or what is absent from us, in a format of short, juxtaposed videos. It was, therefore, yet another marketing campaign for a new musical product, with its own formats and new choreographies, this time tinged with longing for the homelandâ€”what the French people of the past would have calledÂ maladie du pays.
At the same time, kilometers away on the same continent, the new American president, Donald Trump, announced that with him, a new â€œgolden ageâ€ for the United States was beginning. He dismantled the consensus of the previous administration with presidential decrees, setting the political stage for a brave new world. To many analysts, this world bore a dangerous resemblance to the ghosts of the deepest past, and the first accusations quickly followed: nostalgia, nostalgia, nostalgia.
Itâ€™s interesting that both manifestations of this sentiment emerged at the same time, yet are so dissimilar. Over twenty years ago, a Russian exile in Boston, Svetlana Boym, wroteÂ The Future of Nostalgia, likely the most influential work on the contemporary understanding of this feeling. Boym proposed two nostalgic categories: one restorative and the other reflective.Â Restorative nostalgiaÂ would emphasize theÂ nostos, the return home, and characterize those movements that demand a reconstruction of what was lost, a resurgence based on clear and solid identification. This first tendency would define national revivals but, when exaggerated, would also prove highly useful to the far right. The second tendency, however, would beÂ reflective nostalgia, which places weight on theÂ algia, on loss, on pain, on the imperfect process of remembrance. It is not about recovering a truth that once defined us, but about losing ourselves in what the passage of time has made of it: falling in love with the distance that separates us from the ideal and allows us to imagine it.
Thinking in dichotomies appeals to us mainly because itâ€™s comfortable. Although the author intended these categories only as general tendencies, they have been transformed into absolute classifications that provide contemporary analysts with a false sense of certainty. How easy it seems to separate virtuous nostalgias from obscene ones! Thus, it would be simple to attribute Trumpâ€™s project to a â€œrestorativeâ€ nostalgia, emphasizing theÂ again, the return to lost grandeur. Likewise, we could easily label the laments of the Puerto Rican singer, mourning his past on the island and how recent socioeconomic changes threaten his identity, as â€œreflectiveâ€ nostalgia.
Some might say Bad Bunnyâ€™s album offers nothing more than a pastiche of bygone images; in reality, we find in it a preoccupation, above all, with the idea ofÂ homeÂ and its elusive memory. Critics of globalization have warned for decades that in a world where we can feel at home anywhere, we increasingly find ourselves exposed to the elements. Time passes, and in our country, the metaphor becomes literal. What home does nostalgia yearn for in the folds of memory? What dwelling hides so far away, and so deep within? Longing forces us to confront what every home containsâ€”its ghosts. Nostalgia reveals the fictions that construct us: home, origin, memory.
Now, it would seem, a millionaire artist with at least five residences across two continents writes an elegy for the lost home. The president of the worldâ€™s most powerful nation, which has been a root for the uprooted for over two centuries, demands a return to the original home, the reconstruction of a â€œmore authenticâ€ houseâ€”though what he really means is â€œsmaller.â€ At the same time, if the worst omens come true, his decisions will force thousands to abandon their homes in the Gaza Strip; in the United States, hundreds of exiles will be paradoxically forced to return to a country that can no longer be their home, only more hunger and violenceâ€”the very reasons they left so many years ago. Is nostalgia causing all these dramatic decisions, as journalists claim, or are these policies the ones thatÂ will causeÂ even more nostalgia? As always, the nostalgic will not be todayâ€™s reactionaries but the eternally dispossessedâ€”of their land, their lives, and their memories.
Our present reality already denies any discourse claiming that history has ended, that the globalized world has become homogeneous, that reflection, rather than action, is all we have left. Against all simplifications of the nostalgia debate, we must argue that there is no â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€ nostalgia. That would be too easy. There are, instead, many ways to imagine the pastâ€”in truth, we are not allowed to remember in any other way. Nostalgia is merely a specific narrative that expresses unease with the present, a yearning for the future, and a consciousâ€”even idealized, why not?â€”recollection of what has been left behind. If we keep labeling reactionaries as nostalgic, weâ€™ll be handing them another term we need now more than ever: now that our homes are at risk in the hands of vulture funds, now that our homelands burn or are torn apart by water, now that our pasts are reduced toÂ clichÃ©s, we must reclaim our nostalgias and make them converse. We cannot let the far rightâ€™s rhetoric or TikTok trends define their limits and contents.
While some seem to scorn nostalgia, others keep imagining futures against us, or without us. They point, with raised hands, to an authentic home, but we all know a home is more what we wanted it to be than what it will ever become. If we do not reclaim nostalgia, we lose our ability to critique the present. We wonâ€™t be able to question past futures, lost opportunities, or whether our houses were ever truly anyoneâ€™s home.
